definitions: suffering from mental illness or displaying severely disordered behavior
feeling or showing intense anger or extreme annoyance
extremely enthusiastic about something or someone with passionate interest
acting foolishly, recklessly, or without good judgment or reason
examples: The mad patient required specialized psychiatric care and treatment
He went completely mad after years of isolation
She was absolutely mad at him for lying about everything
The customer got mad when the order was wrong again
He's mad about vintage motorcycles and collects them obsessively
The teenagers are mad about that new pop singer
It was mad to drive in such terrible weather conditions
That's a mad idea that will never work out

definitions: marked by wild, reckless, or impulsive behavior; amusingly eccentric
examples: Their madcap adventure took them across three continents unexpectedly
She had another madcap scheme to make money quickly

definitions: having been manufactured, created, or produced in a specified way
having achieved success or reached an established position in life
examples: The handmade furniture was expensive but worth every penny
These shoes are made of genuine Italian leather
He's a made man in the organization now
After that promotion, she's got it made financially

definitions: of a bright purplish-red color between red and purple
examples: She wore a striking magenta dress to the gallery opening
The sunset turned the clouds magenta and orange

definitions: having or appearing to have supernatural powers or qualities
wonderfully exciting or delightful; having special charm or appeal
examples: The magic potion transformed the frog into a prince
She waved her magic wand over the enchanted forest
It was a magic moment when they won the championship
The restaurant has a magic atmosphere perfect for romance

definitions: relating to or using magic or supernatural powers and forces
beautiful or delightful in a way that seems removed from everyday life
examples: The wizard possessed magical abilities beyond human comprehension
Ancient cultures believed in magical rituals for good harvests
The wedding was a magical evening under the stars
Children find the first snowfall absolutely magical every year

definitions: having or showing great authority and confidence; commanding and dignified
relating to a magistrate or the office of magistrate
examples: Her magisterial presence commanded respect from everyone present
He delivered a magisterial analysis of economic policy
The magisterial duties included presiding over minor criminal cases
She assumed her magisterial responsibilities with great seriousness

definitions: generous in forgiving an insult or injury; free from petty resentfulness
examples: He was magnanimous in victory and praised his opponents
Her magnanimous gesture of forgiveness surprised everyone present

definitions: having the properties of a magnet; exhibiting magnetism or attraction
very attractive or alluring; having a powerful charm or appeal
examples: The magnetic field disrupted the compass readings significantly
Iron filings align themselves along magnetic field lines
She had a magnetic personality that drew people naturally
His magnetic charm made him perfect for sales

definitions: having been made magnetic or given magnetic properties through exposure
examples: The magnetized needle always points toward magnetic north
The tools became magnetized after years near the magnet

definitions: extremely beautiful, elaborate, or impressive; inspiring great admiration or awe
examples: The palace had magnificent gardens stretching for miles
She gave a magnificent performance that earned standing ovations

definitions: enlarged or made to appear larger through optical or other means
increased in importance or effect; made to seem greater than reality
examples: The magnified image revealed tiny details invisible normally
The cells appeared clearly under the magnified view
His small mistake was magnified by the media coverage
Fear magnified the danger in her worried mind

definitions: being the first or earliest of its kind; initial or inaugural
examples: The ship's maiden voyage ended in complete disaster
She won her maiden tournament after years of trying

definitions: sent through the postal system or electronic mail service
protected or covered with armor made of metal rings or plates
examples: The mailed invitations arrived two weeks before the wedding
All mailed packages require proper postage and addressing
The mailed knight rode into battle heavily protected
His mailed fist struck the wooden shield powerfully

definitions: wounded or injured so that part of the body is permanently damaged
examples: The maimed soldier struggled to adapt to civilian life
Many workers were maimed in the factory accident

definitions: chief in size or importance; principal or primary among others
examples: The main reason for leaving was better opportunities
Turn left at the main entrance of the building

definitions: kept in good condition through regular care and repairs
continued at the same level or rate without interruption
examples: The well maintained garden looked beautiful throughout the year
Their maintained equipment rarely broke down during operations
She maintained her composure despite the shocking news
He maintained his innocence throughout the lengthy trial

definitions: having or showing impressive beauty or dignity; grand and awe-inspiring
examples: The majestic mountains rose above the morning clouds
Eagles soared with majestic grace across the sky

definitions: important, serious, or significant in effect or consequence
greater in scale, extent, or importance than others of its kind
examples: Climate change is a major concern for future generations
She made a major contribution to medical research
The major highways connect all the important cities
He underwent major surgery to repair the damage

definitions: serving as a temporary substitute; improvised and often of inferior quality
examples: They built a makeshift shelter from branches and leaves
The makeshift hospital treated hundreds of earthquake victims

definitions: not adjusting adequately or appropriately to the environment or situation; counterproductive
examples: His maladaptive behavior patterns required professional therapeutic intervention
Chronic stress can lead to maladaptive coping mechanisms

definitions: relating to or affected by malaria, a mosquito-borne infectious disease
examples: The malarial regions require special health precautions for travelers
She suffered from malarial fever for several weeks

definitions: of or denoting the sex that produces spermatozoa for reproduction
examples: The male lion has a distinctive mane around his head
Male pattern baldness affects millions of men worldwide

definitions: having or showing a wish to do evil to others; hostile and harmful
examples: The villain's malevolent smile sent shivers down their spines
She cast a malevolent glance at her rival

definitions: abnormally or badly formed or shaped; having an irregular structure
examples: The malformed bone required corrective surgery to fix properly
Several malformed specimens were removed from the production line

definitions: failing to function normally or satisfactorily; not working properly
examples: The malfunctioning equipment caused delays in production yesterday
A malfunctioning brake system led to the accident

definitions: characterized by malice; intending or intended to do harm deliberately
examples: The malicious rumors destroyed her reputation within weeks
Hackers launched malicious attacks on government websites

definitions: evil in nature or effect; malevolent or harmful in influence
examples: The dictator's malign influence spread throughout the region
A malign tumor was discovered during the examination

definitions: of a disease, very virulent or infectious; specifically cancerous
evil in nature or effect; malevolent and dangerous
examples: The malignant tumor required immediate surgical removal
Tests confirmed the growth was malignant rather than benign
His malignant narcissism destroyed every relationship he had
The malignant ideology spread through vulnerable communities

definitions: able to be hammered or pressed into shape without breaking
easily influenced or changed; adaptable and impressionable
examples: Gold is highly malleable and can be beaten very thin
The malleable metal was perfect for detailed craftwork
Young minds are malleable and shaped by their experiences
His malleable personality adapted to any social situation

definitions: suffering from malnutrition; not having enough food or the right food
examples: The malnourished children needed immediate medical attention urgently
Many malnourished animals were rescued from the facility

definitions: containing malt or malt extract; flavored with germinated grain
examples: She ordered a chocolate malted milkshake from the diner
Malted barley is essential for brewing quality beer

definitions: relating to or characteristic of mammals, warm-blooded vertebrate animals
examples: Mammalian species nurse their young with milk produced naturally
The mammalian brain evolved complex emotional systems

definitions: relating to the human breast or milk-secreting organs of mammals
examples: The mammary glands produce milk for feeding offspring
She underwent mammary reconstruction surgery after cancer treatment

definitions: huge; of very great size or proportions; enormous and impressive
examples: The company faced a mammoth task reorganizing after merger
They discovered mammoth footprints preserved in ancient rock

definitions: able to be managed, controlled, or accomplished without great difficulty
examples: Breaking the project into manageable chunks made it easier
Her hair became more manageable after using the conditioner

definitions: relating to management or managers, especially in business organizations
examples: She developed strong managerial skills through years of experience
The managerial team decided to restructure the department

definitions: required by law or rules; compulsory and not optional or voluntary
examples: Attendance at the safety briefing is absolutely mandatory
The state introduced mandatory testing for all students

definitions: able to be maneuvered; capable of changing direction or position easily
examples: The small boat was highly maneuverable in tight spaces
Fighter jets must be maneuverable for combat effectiveness

definitions: severely mutilated, disfigured, or damaged by cutting, tearing, or crushing
examples: The mangled wreckage showed the crash's devastating force
His mangled hand required multiple reconstructive surgeries

definitions: showing wild or violent behavior; excessively enthusiastic about something
examples: He drives like a complete maniac on the highway
She's a maniac cleaner who disinfects everything twice

definitions: showing wild, violent, or uncontrolled behavior; exhibiting extreme enthusiasm
examples: His maniacal laughter echoed through the empty building
She worked with maniacal determination to finish first

definitions: showing the symptoms of mania; abnormally elevated mood and energy
showing wild and apparently deranged excitement and energy
examples: The patient's manic episodes required immediate medical intervention
His manic behavior worried his family and friends
The manic pace of city life exhausted her completely
They worked at a manic speed to meet deadline

definitions: clear or obvious to the eye or mind; plainly evident
examples: Her manifest talent impressed everyone at the audition
The manifest unfairness of the decision angered many

definitions: many and varied; having many different forms, features, or elements
examples: The manifold benefits of exercise include mental health improvements
She faced manifold challenges in her new position

definitions: exercising unscrupulous control or influence over a person or situation
examples: Her manipulative behavior destroyed several close friendships permanently
He used manipulative tactics to get his way

definitions: having qualities traditionally associated with men, especially strength and courage
examples: His manly handshake conveyed confidence and strength
She admired his manly determination to protect others

definitions: having a human crew or staff present and operating
examples: The manned spacecraft successfully reached the space station
All checkpoints must be manned throughout the night

definitions: having manners of a specified kind; behaving in particular way
having an artificial or stilted style or character
examples: The well mannered children impressed all the dinner guests
His mannered way of speaking seemed old-fashioned
Her mannered prose style made the novel difficult reading
The actor's mannered performance distracted from the story

definitions: able to be maneuvered; capable of being moved or directed easily
examples: The compact car is highly manoeuvrable in city traffic
These manoeuvrable boats excel in narrow waterways
